Problem:
Consider a complex function governed by \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit, and the dynamical system is characterized by \\( \\dot{z} = Pz + Q \\) with constant matrices P and Q. We explore how the system behaves with respect to the transformation \\( h(z) = e^{Mt}z \\) where M is another constant matrix.

If \\( h(z) \\) is applied to a vector \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\dot{z} = Pz + Q\\) without further interventions, will the state \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be equivalent to the evolution from \\( z_0 \\) to t = T under \\(\\dot{z} = Pz + Q\\) without the transformation?
Explanation: Applying \\( h(z) = e^{Mt}z \\) fundamentally alters the initial condition by scaling and rotating \\( z_0 \\), thus the trajectory of \\( z(t) \\) will evolve differently due to the effects of M on the dynamics established by P and Q.
